ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: AMAZING! learned so much asl in a short amount of time and the learning environment was very healthy. All of the professors are great and very understanding. Class is community minded and not too much work but still very valuable.
I learned many new signs, new classifiers, how to tell stories, poems, more about ASL as a language, deaf culture,  and the deaf community. My skills in ASL greatly improved.
I learned about Deaf Culture and signs!
Knowledge in fluency of signing, particularly towards requests, directions, expanded vocabulary, and varied grammar.
I learned the basic grammar structure of American Sign Language and progressed in my vocabulary skills.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: only four days a week, learn so much, good for Lang requirement, small workload, nice people and professors 
Weaknesses: pretty much none

The strengths:
- the content
- the organization
- the professor

The weaknesses:
- the online textbook
- the required hours for outside service work

Strengths: lots of opportunities to practice signing in and out of class. The class really cultivates a community and friendship, and the signing only classroom space was a low stakes way to really improve signing skills. We had a good mix of practicing after models and forming our own stories/sentences which I think was good for language acquisition.

Weaknesses: Sometimes in pair work, other students didn't understand the direction so the time was spent trying explain what the prompt was. I wish that that could have been clarified more. Class also frequently started late. Since class is short to begin with, it was hard to feel like we got through the material in that time.

The department is wonderful. The teachers all care about their students and the class format reflects that. The final project is a window for you to explore anything you want, and the classes are paced and managed with students in mind. Since the department is expanding, it can occasionally be hard to keep up with class logistics, but the professors are incredibly understanding.

A major strength is the 4 day / 1 day asynchronous model of teaching. The service projects force the students to get involved with the deaf community at Yale and in New Haven, thereby enhancing their learning. The students would not do this otherwise and so this is a great way to help increase the students' involvement. One weakness is that the different professors have different signing variations for some signs. This makes exams difficult if the video is made by another professor (not your own) and they use a different sign variation.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend this 100%. Its an important life skill and the class is well structured.

Yes! 100%! I think it is important to learn sign language, and the class is an incredible experience. You learn so much and have fun doing it. You not only learn a language, but you learn about a whole community.
Yes! Take ASL! It's a really fun and chill class, and you'll learn so much about the Deaf community/accessibility and Deaf culture along the way.
Absolutely!! Favorite class Ive taken at yale.
Yes!!! Take ASL, it really comes into play even as you navigate Yale's campus. The department is amazing and cares about students, their learning, and the community.

I would absolutely recommend this to another student! I think ASL is often overlooked when considering a second language. Taking time to learn this visual language really stretches your brain in a different way than learning auditory languages. I think everyone should learn ASL at some point because it is useful in many situations for hearing people as well
